question.content:

hints.content: Because each square has an area of $1$ square unit, we can count the shaded squares to find the area.

First, we count the number of $\green{\text{complete unit squares}}$.   
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7433f4a54f2073f66f9696e1696f8af10fefadfc)  
There are $\green {8\text{ complete unit squares}}$.
We can combine the $8$ half-filled squares to make $\blue {4 \text{ complete unit squares}}$.
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e449c0d5cae2db9d1bbdce129141fcb74a518d2d)

Add the $\green {8\text{ square units}}$ and $\blue {4 \text{ square units}}$.  

$\green{8} + \blue {4} = 12$
The area of the shape is $12$ square units.

hints.content:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4272bd6ea2f7ff7e660ed4a04c7362ab73dde7d5)
We can find the area of a square by multiplying the length by the width.

$\text{Area }= \blueD{5} \text{ units} \times 5\text{ units}$

question.content:
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e80f7eca9751ce24d6ec0d5f5a416a29b3f335eb) is $1$ unit square.

$\text{Area }= $ [[☃ numeric-input 7]]  square units

hints.content: We can find the area of Rectangle $A$ by multiplying the length and width.

We can find the length and width of the rectangle by counting the unit squares along each side.

$\text{Area }= \text{length} \times \text{width}$ 

$\text{Area }= 5 \text{ units}\times6 \text{ units}$

question.content:
![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/198a6ca026fc78a1e02af0c3256348dc480e6409) is $1$ unit square.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/91a6eb011627389a0b6a98c3a5396b26c51d8de7)

hints.content: ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0811182279cf2e7dc1e99193fdbcada606ea9c8c)
The area is the length times the width.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dbab7d96296dc1f3456b5a87ca5bd7069c1f019e)

  The length is $7$ units. The width is $3$ units. So the area is $7\times3$ square units.

$ \qquad\text{area} = 7 \times 3 = 21 $

  We can also count $21$ square units. 

 ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a979ab2437fa2b16c530336eaf177c35290e0efe)

question.content:
** A rectangle is $7$ units long and $3$ units wide. What is its area? **

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] square units

hints.content: ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0811015195d3ad9df0c067ddc7d37e4e6db66493)

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d48f2f3240fb56476955f377050187182a09411c)

  The area is the length times the width. 

 $\qquad \pink{\text{?}} \times \pink{\text{?}} = 16\text{ m} $

$\qquad \pink{4} \times \pink{4} = 16\text{ m} $

  The sides of a square are all the same length, so each side must be $4$ meters long.

question.content:
** The area of a square is $16$ square meters. How long is each side? **

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] meters

hints.content: The distance around a closed figure is called its perimeter.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6f4dcfed48a8a4d282d0de377496573f5999234f)


To find the perimeter, we add the lengths of all $4$ sides.

$6+6+6+6= \text{ ?}$
The perimeter is $24$ units.

The perimeter of the rectangle is $98$ meters.

question.content:
**What is the perimeter of the quadrilateral?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] meters

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0e56b7ecdd1d9ac1e3fa8bf7405a699952b8046e)

hints.content: The distance around a closed figure is called its perimeter.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1533d5faa174de926f19ace983d0ec5fac2db9fe)  

The sum of all the known lengths is:

$\redC{7} + \greenD{3} + \gray{4} + \blueD{7} = \maroonD{{21}\,\text{cm}}$.

The total perimeter is $26\,\text{cm}$.  

Subtract the known lengths from  $26\,\text{cm}$ to find the missing length.  

$26 - \maroonD{21} = \purpleC{5\,\text{ cm}}$
The missing side length is  $\purpleC {5\,\text{cm}}$.

question.content:
The perimeter of the figure is $26\text{ cm}$.   (Figure not drawn to scale)

 **What is the length of the missing side?**  
[[☃ input-number 1]] $\text{cm}$

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9a3c413be0514b7a48ea00d98648f41cf73ea1a8.png)

hints.content: The distance around a closed figure is called its perimeter.

One of the side lengths is missing!  

Let's split figure into rectangles.  That will help us figure out the missing length.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d7de8aee35ff9f4a87b496204f7d2952a64dfc4a)

Opposite sides of a rectangle have the same length.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3d60f6e1bcb097988e938be671dd53ac204b33e5)

We can make the following equation.

$\greenD{2} + \blueD{2} + \maroonD{?} = 7$

That's the same as:

$4 + \maroonD{?} =7$

The missing side length is $\maroonD{3\text{ m}}$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a04eb7a4d6b4c978a8cc85c66e55dbfe3648b6d6)

Add all of the side lengths together to find the perimeter.

$\text{Perimeter} = 7 + 5 + 2 + 3 + \maroonD{3} + 4 + 2 + 6$
The perimeter is $32$ meters.

question.content:
The figure below is made of rectangles.  

**What is the perimeter of the figure below?**  
*Note that not all side lengths are labeled.*

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\text{m}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2d476bce041549cd5c54ad8fde2176e701251191)

answers.message: One of the lengths is missing.

hints.content:
First, let's find the length of one side of the backyard.



$P =  \blueD{s} +  \blueD{s}+ \blueD{s}+ \blueD{s}$  
$P = 4\blueD{s}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8c0b7204dbfbf1585ca1389b85c7e31eaded241b)

The perimeter of the backyard is $\greenD{56}$ meters.  


$\greenD{56}= 4\blueD{s}$

What number can be multiplied by $4$ to get $\greenD{56}$?

We can divide to find the side length.  

$\greenD{56}\div4= \blueD{14}$

One side of the backyard is $\blueD{14}$ meters.

Now, we can find the area.  

$A = \blueD{s}^2 $   
$A = \blueD{s} \times \blueD{s}$   
$A = \blueD{14} \times \blueD{14}$
The area of Jonah's backyard is $196$ square meters.

question.content:
The perimeter of Jonah's square backyard is $56$ meters.

**What is the area of Jonah's backyard?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] square meters

hints.content: Volume is measured by counting the number of cubic units.

So, we can count the number of unit cubes.   
*Some of the cubes might be hidden behind other cubes. Try to visualize all of the cubes.*
The volume of the prism is $25$ cubic units.

question.content:
Unit cube:  
 ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/80a55fe49152df92865fd39a03af52ce356f9c1d)    

**What is the volume of the rectangular prism?**  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ec03a3be2ab3a2ff39254aa6c4ca19151a4657ce)

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] unit cubes

hints.content: Volume is measured by counting the number of cubic units.

So, we can count the number of unit cubes.   
*Some of the cubes might be hidden behind other cubes. Try to visualize all of the cubes.*

We can also look at the layers.

We can count $\greenD4$ cubes on each layer of the prism.


There are $\blueD3$ layers, so we can find the total number of cubes by multiplying.
  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/210d21e6d891c2107f061bf1ad867777f57f6a63)

$\greenD4\times \blueD3= \Box$
The volume of the prism is $12$ cubic units.

question.content:
Unit cube:  
 ![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/80a55fe49152df92865fd39a03af52ce356f9c1d)    

**What is the volume of the rectangular prism?**  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d25439068353f4f6360db06f48cb2cdd3e5b8107)

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] unit cubes

hints.content: We want to know how many one-centimeter cubes can we fit in the prism.

### Step 1: Find the area of the base

First, let's figure out how many fit at the bottom (base) of the shape.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/782e0fb1e0e108cf82430d62adc135ba1914ff75)

We can fit $8\times 2=16$ unit cubes at the base.

**Note:** The base of this prism is a rectangle, which is why we call it a rectangular prism. The area of the base is $16 \text{ cm}^2$.

### Step 2: Multiply by the height of the prism

One layer of cubes has $16$ cubes. But, how many layers fit in the prism?

We can fit $3$ layers of cubes in the prism because its height is $3\text{ cm}$.

Multiplying, we get

$16\times 3=48$ cubes

which means the volume of the prism is $48\text{ cm}^3$.

The answer:

$48 \text{ cm}^3$

question.content:
**What is the volume of the rectangular prism?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\text{cm}^3$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4715282939ccecb9c738af2d8298c9e4ebb7fc37)

hints.content: We want to know how many one-centimeter cubes can we fit in the prism.

### Step 1: Find the area of the base

First, let's figure out how many fit at the bottom (base) of the shape.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ab9dd4aaaec3f0acbf414dfc33ec461fd399a685)

We can fit $4\times 3=12$ unit cubes at the base.

**Note:** The base of this prism is a rectangle, which is why we call it a rectangular prism. The area of the base is $12 \text{ cm}^2$.

### Step 2: Multiply by the height of the prism

One layer of cubes has $12$ cubes. But, how many layers fit in the prism?

We can fit $2$ layers of cubes in the prism because its height is $2\text{ cm}$.

Multiplying, we get

$12\times 2=24$ cubes

which means the volume of the prism is $24\text{ cm}^3$.

The answer:

$24 \text{ cm}^3$

question.content:
**What is the volume of the rectangular prism?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] $\text{cm}^3$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3dd04ecbd018518c6ffebd3d60b2b1cab5ba0dc4)

hints.content: Volume of a rectangular prism can be found by using the formula $V=length\times width\times height$.

Let's plug in the choices and see when we get a volume of $\green{210}$ square centimeters.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1135ae45feee1934ed0ecfcec1c5239e1d214c8b.png)  
$\pink{15}\times\pink2\times\pink7=\green{210}$  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8b3798d7dc1eb610c8cc2abc52881fac058c3cf6.png)    
$\gray7\times\gray3\times\gray{10}=\green{210}$  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f528828cc22dde1e103458fb6ec5ba7f17c6dd86.png)    
$\blue{14}\times\blue{3}\times\blue{7}=\red{294}$

The dimensions of the box could be the following:

- $15\text{ cm}$ long, $2\text{ cm}$  wide, $7\text{ cm}$  high
- $7\text{ cm}$ long, $3\text{ cm}$  wide, $10\text{ cm}$  high

question.content:
I bought a box of granola bars at the store that has a volume of $210$ cubic centimeters.

**Which of the following could be the dimensions of my box?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.content: $15\text{ cm}$ long, $2\text{ cm}$  wide, $7\text{ cm}$  high
$7\text{ cm}$  long, $3\text{ cm}$  wide, $10\text{ cm}$  high
$14\text{ cm}$  long, $3\text{ cm}$  wide, $7\text{ cm}$  high
